They probably recorded this at 60FPS and used a plugin called "Twixtor" to do a time warp. While they did not get every single frame of the can being crushed, Twixtor interpolated what was happening this those moments between each frame. This can cause warping in the slow motion as the program is trying to piece what happens in between each frame. True Slow Motion is caused by shooting something at a high FPS ( e.g. 1000 FPS) and playing it back at a lower one (e.g. 25 FPS) causing 40x slowdown.

The water is NOT doing the crushing. First of all, when water cools, it doesn't expand, it contracts. They're pouring water on the drum to cool the water vapor INSIDE the drum to liquid water. Since water vapor CONTRACTS into liquid water, less of the volume of the drum is taken up, and the OUTSIDE air pushes it in. Basically, when the gas inside turns into a liquid, it contracts, and the air outside pushes it in. That is why the drum gets crushed.
Note you would need one heck of a stopper to hold the pressure in required to reverse the process. :)

If the drum were weak enough to be broken by an atmosphere of internal pressure, then it will break.  The space shuttle doesn't explode because the people who designed it did so in a way to be sure it could contain the pressure that it is designed to contain.

If you put more pressure inside the space shuttle than it was designed to contain, it could explode.  Likewise if you put more pressure inside the drum than it can contain, it will explode.

If either has a tiny hole, they will just leak.

Excellent question.  The answer is: maybe.  It depends on the strength of the drum in relation to the internal pressure.  You may be thinking that if atmospheric pressure is enough to crush it, then atmospheric pressure is enough to explode it.  But in practice, it's actually easier to hold in more pressure than it is to keep pressure out.

The Mythbusters diver suit experiment is just like what happens with the drum in this video. It's the opposite of the man in space scenario. There (and in the video), the pressure outside is greater than the pressure inside. When a man is exposed to vacuum, it's the inner pressure that is greater than the outside vacuum pressure. Pressure is simply force over an area so there is a force pushing on the drum from the inside as well as the outside. However, since the water vapor was cooled down, there weren't as many gas molecules pushing on the drum from the inside. When the force from the gas molecules hitting the outside of the container becomes sufficiently greater than the force from the molecules hitting the inside of the container, the drum implodes.

You do not explode. Your blood does not boil. You do not freeze. You do not instantly lose consciousness. Various minor problems (sunburn, possibly "the bends", certainly some [mild, reversible, painless] swelling of skin and underlying tissue) start after ten seconds or so. At some point you lose consciousness from lack of oxygen. Injuries accumulate. After perhaps one or two minutes, you're dying. The limits are not really known.

How long can a human live unprotected in space?
If you don't try to hold your breath, exposure to space for half a minute or so is unlikely to produce permanent injury. Holding your breath is likely to damage your lungs, something scuba divers have to watch out for when ascending, and you'll have eardrum trouble if your Eustachian tubes are badly plugged up, but theory predicts -- and animal experiments confirm -- that otherwise, exposure to vacuum causes no immediate injury.
